addressleaf.section:
To
e right worship
ll
my very Lovinge frende M
r
Thomas Bodley Esq
r
, one of her M
ty
Counselers in
e Counsel of state of
e united Provinces at
e Hage.

19 Oct
o
89 From M
r
Secretary

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 19 Octo
b
To M
r
Bodly
S
r
I perceive by yo
r
l
re
how hardely and against
all humanitie you have bin used at the states handes in
this case of
Vasseurs,
touching yo
r
last direction therin
received from me in her
Ma
tes
name, I have bin my self
imployed in sondry services and legations as yow know
yet did I never meete w
th
such intemperat disordered
humors in [princes] that might in better reason have
held somme such extraordinarie a course, w
th
a messen
ger of a princes then these sort of governors, the
meanest of all the kindes of magistrates, And by
reason of the information given yow that the ground of
his their uncivil and barborous procedinge should spring
from their deputies on this side, I charged them w
th
it,
but w
th
sole
m
e protestations they denyed that ever any
such matter proceded from them and offred to make good
so much under their handes, shewing further the discon
tentement they received that the states should so farre
misgoverne them selves towardes her M
te
, who could not
but be touched in the misrage of the parson of her servant
and would at their comming home let them understand
how fouly they had forgotten them selves, and in liew of
somme kynd of satisfaction, in that behalf, procurethe
libertie of the prisoner that hath bin so longe suted for,
so that at their repaire and accesse to the states
yow shall do well to urge them to accomplishement of
their promise in way of satisfaction of those errors
committed against yow, and forbeare to make any more
motion to them in her M
tes
name, whome in case I had
acquainted w
th
this manner of dealing of theirs, they
should have receaved an other kynde of message then
yet they do, or by their deputies they can understand
fol.146v
M
r
Bodley
As for the matter of
Ostend
by reason of the great insta
nce that hath ben made to her M
te
uppon report of
the great extremitie of hasard it standeth in, there was
purposely w
th
all expedition dispatched over,
M
r
Adams
to survey the breaches, and the worke requisite to be
made for the safetie of the towne. But
by
his report of
the view, and acoumpt of the charges that it will requi
re, it appeareth the worke that is reqisit can not be
done w
th
out the expenses of fiftene or sixtene hondred
poundes, and the contribution that the states seme to
have yelded towardes the same, semeth not to amount
to much more then one hundred poundes, so that the
states must truely take order for convenient meanes
or reliefe to furnish that charges or her M
te
will a
bandonne it,
And so w
th
my verie hartie commenda
tions I leave yow to god From the Co
r
te at
Richmond the 19 of October
1589
Yo
r
verie Loving frend
Francis Walsyngham
S
r
, my M
r
willed me to send yow heerw
th
e Deputies
last negotiation w
th
e
LL.
w
th
their apostilles thereunto, and wold
moreover have yow to let
Count Hollock
to understand,
t
her M
tie
hath bin so farre from gevinge any eare, much lesse
credit, to
e report
t
have bin deliv
r
d out of here touchinge
e actions of
Gertrudenbergh,
as
t
he may wel assured him self
there is no noblem
a
of his qualitie,
t
resteth more setled in her
good opinion then he doeth. As by her owne letters he shall right
wel perceive. and therefore could have wished her not labored
his good friendes to mediate a hearinge of his just defence in
t
matter.
